dlentry.dd: The version of Java bundled with requires X.org (Wayland is not supported).

section.title: Linux Installer
section.p:
To install using the Linux installer, follow these steps:
Make sure that your system meets the system requirements.
Download the Linux installer.
[Optional] Validate the integrity of the downloaded file by checking it against the MD5 sum published on the download page.
Run the installer and follow the instructions in the installation program.For example, open a shell, cd to the installation directory, and at the prompt type sh ./oxygen-64bit-openjdk.shsh ./oxygenAuthor-64bit-openjdk.shsh ./oxygenDeveloper-64bit-openjdk.shsh ./oxygenJSON-64bit-openjdk.sh.If you are running the installer as root and your Linux distribution uses Wayland (such as Ubuntu 17.10 or Fedora 25), before running the installer, the local user must first allow the root user to access the X server by running the following command (as the local user):xhost +SI:localuser:root
Start using one of the following methods:
Use the oxygenauthordeveloperjsoneditorsyncroSVNClient shortcut created by the installer.For Ubuntu 17.10 (or later), a security dialog box will appear the first time you start the application where you need to select Trust and Launch to continue. This dialog box will not appear on subsequent launches.
From a command line, type sh oxygen.shsh oxygenAuthor.shsh oxygenDeveloper.shsh oxygenJSONEditor.shsh syncroSVNClient.sh. This file is located in the installation folder.
To license your copy of go to Help Register and enter your license information.

section.title: Linux Unattended Installation
section.p: You can run the installation in unattended mode by running the installer from the command line with the -q parameter. By default, running the installer in unattended mode installs with the default options and does not overwrite existing files. You can change various options for the unattended installer using the installer command-line parameters.

section.title: Linux Installer Command-Line Reference
section.p: The installer for Linux supports a variety of command-line parameters:

dlentry.dd: Instructs the installer to run in unattended mode. The installer will not prompt the user for input during the install. Default settings will be used for all options unless a response.varfile is specified using the -varfile option.

In unattended mode, the installer does not overwrite files with the same name if a previous version of the is installed in the same folder. The -overwrite parameter added after the -q parameter forces the overwriting of these files.
Displays a console during the installation.
Specifies the location of a response.varfile, normally to be used during an unattended installation.

section.title: Linux Installer response.varfile
section.p: The installer for Linux also creates a file called response.varfile, which records the choices that the user made when running the installer interactively. The generated response file is found in the [OXYGEN_INSTALL_DIR]/.install4j folder. You can use the response.varfile to set the options for an unintended install. For more information about the response.varfile format, see install4j site.
